tendency.comment:
Trend until Monday, 25.03.2024

Snow will continue to fall to low altitudes in the north from Saturday evening until Sunday night into Monday. In Valais, on the Northern Alpine Ridge and in northern Grisons, 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall. In the south, it will be mostly dry and quite sunny during the day. The wind will blow strongly from the west. On Monday it will be sunny in all regions during the day. The zero-degree level will rise a little during the day, moving back towards 2000 m. The wind will be mostly light in the early morning, with moderate winds from the south in the afternoon.

The danger of dry avalanches will increase in the north on Sunday, decreasing again somewhat on Monday. In the other regions, it will remain largely unchanged. In the north, moist snow slides from the new fallen snow are to be expected on Monday as a result of solar radiation and warmer daytime temperatures. Gliding avalanches will still be possible on both days.

weatherReview.comment:
Weather review for Friday, 22.03.2024

A little precipitation continued to fall in the north and east on Thursday evening. The snowfall level was around 2200 m. The night was partly clear and it was quite sunny during the day.

New snow

A few centimetres fell in some localities.

Temperature

At midday at 2000 m, around +6 °C.

Wind

  • There were moderate to strong northerly winds during the first half of the night on the Northern Alpine Ridge and on and to the south of the Main Alpine Ridge.
  • Otherwise winds were mostly light to moderate.

weatherForecast.comment:
Weather forecast until Saturday, 23.03.2024

After a partly clear night, widespread precipitation will fall in the north during the day. There will also be some bright spells in the afternoon. The snowfall level will drop rapidly from around 2000 m to 1000 m. It will be dry and fairly sunny in the south.

New snow

From Saturday morning to Saturday afternoon, the following amounts of fresh snow are expected above 2200 m:

  • northern flank of the Alps, not including the Prealps: 10 to 20 cm;
  • less elsewhere, dry in the south.

Temperature

At midday at 2000 m, -5 °C in the north and +1 °C in the south.

Wind

There will be a westerly wind:

  • strong to storm force in the north and generally at high altitudes;
  • elsewhere light to moderate during the night, increasing during the day.

avalancheProblems.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and westerly wind, wind slabs will form. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. The avalanches can reach medium size.
Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2+) in west to northeast to southeast facing aspects above 2000m.

avalancheProblems.comment: In particular on steep grassy slopes occasionally large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. As a consequence of solar radiation moist snow slides are possible.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2) in all aspects below 2600m.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Snowpack

Some of the fresh and somewhat older drift snow and near-surface layers are prone to triggering. Around the crusts in older layers in the upper part of the snowpack, weak layers with a sometimes faceted crystal structure are deposited, especially on shady slopes at high altitudes. Deep layers of the snowpack are compact in many places and for the most part do not contain distinct weak layers.

The snowpack is soaked up to approximately 3000 m on south-facing slopes, up to 2000-2400 m on east- and west-facing slopes, and up to approximately 1800-2000 m on north-facing slopes.

Gliding avalanches are still possible, especially on east-, south- and west-facing slopes below approximately 2600 m and on north-facing slopes below approximately 2000 m. These may be large.

weatherForecast.comment:
Weather forecast until Saturday, 23.03.2024

After a partly clear night, widespread precipitation will fall in the north during the day. There will also be some bright spells in the afternoon. The snowfall level will drop rapidly from around 2000 m to 1000 m. It will be dry and fairly sunny in the south.

New snow

From Saturday morning to Saturday afternoon, the following amounts of fresh snow are expected above 2200 m:

  • northern flank of the Alps, not including the Prealps: 10 to 20 cm;
  • less elsewhere, dry in the south.

Temperature

At midday at 2000 m, -5 °C in the north and +1 °C in the south.

Wind

There will be a westerly wind:

  • strong to storm force in the north and generally at high altitudes;
  • elsewhere light to moderate during the night, increasing during the day.

avalancheProblems.comment:
As a consequence of a strong westerly wind, mostly small wind slabs will form. They are in some cases prone to triggering. Additionally in some places avalanches can also be released in near-surface layers of the snowpack and reach medium size.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for careful route selection.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2=) in west to northeast to southeast facing aspects above 2200m.

avalancheProblems.comment: In particular on steep grassy slopes occasionally large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. As a consequence of solar radiation moist snow slides are possible.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2) in all aspects below 2600m.

The snowpack is soaked up to approximately 3000 m on south-facing slopes, up to 2000-2400 m on east- and west-facing slopes, and up to approximately 1800-2000 m on north-facing slopes.

Gliding avalanches are still possible, especially on east-, south- and west-facing slopes below approximately 2600 m and on north-facing slopes below approximately 2000 m. These may be large.

CH.coreZoneText: Danger level "moderate" (2) in all aspects below 2600m.

avalancheProblems.comment:
Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in extremely steep terrain.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

Gliding avalanches are still possible, especially on east-, south- and west-facing slopes below approximately 2600 m and on north-facing slopes below approximately 2000 m. These may be large.
